Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Genetic System Directing Multicellular Development of Myxococcales

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Myxobacteria are distinguished among bacteria by a multicellular stage in their life cycle known as fruiting bodies. Preliminary evidence suggests that this transition from single cell to multicellular fruiting body is regulated by light. The primary goal of this project is to establish a set of novel, previously untested yet potentially transformative genetic tools that can be applied broadly in bacterial studies but are used here to examine the light induced transition to multicellularity in Myxobacteria. Determining the mechanisms underlying this multicellular process in Myxobacteria could have important implications for understanding the evolution of more complex pathways seen in multicellular eukaryotes, which include most higher organisms. Undergraduate and graduate students will receive training in multidisciplinary state-of-the-art research methods and techniques including bacterial genetics and structural biochemistry and biophysics. In addition, over 75 students will be exposed to research experiences during completion of undergraduate courses in biochemistry and molecular biology.


The genetic mechanisms underlying fruiting body formation are not conserved in Myxococcales resulting in variations in the fruiting morphology and the role of visible light as an essential environmental signal. The reasons for this relative lack of conservation are unknown. Development of a novel genetic system for examining and testing the plasticity of this unique multicellular program is vital to answering how a complex developmental pathway responds to various genetic changes. The proposed genetic system will be used to support exploratory work on how light controls fruiting body formation in non-photosynthetic Myxobacteria. Genes that code for a) the bacterial photoreceptors that perceive and respond to light and b) the circadian clock KaiC homolog of cyanobacteria are found across all three suborders of Myxococcales, yet their role in non-photosynthetic bacteria remain largely unknown. Genetically, the best characterized M. xanthus doesn't contain either of these genes, but closely related M. fulvus does. How have the two pathways adapted to these differences? By using a comparative analysis of closely related, yet distinctly different species, M. xanthus and M. fulvus, the investigators will be able to approach this question without the complexity inherent with more diverse Myxobacteria. Insertion mutations via plasmid integration mutagenesis and in-frame deletions using insertion-excision mutagenesis, based on tools available for M. xanthus, will be developed in M. fulvus. This genetic system will allow characterization of the biochemical function of the red-light photoreceptor known as bacteriophytochrome and the circadian clock KaiC homolog, to define the role of these proteins in Myxococcales development. In addition, the developmental transcriptome of M. fulvus in the light and dark will be compared along with a comparison of the M. fulvus developmental transcriptome to that of M. xanthus to determine similarities and differences in developmental gene expression between these two close relatives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Non-photosynthetic Myxobacteria are distinguished among prokaryotes by a multicellular stage in their life cycle known as fruiting bodies. The genetic mechanisms underlying fruiting body formation are not conserved in Myxococcales resulting in variations in the fruiting morphology and visible light as the essential environmental signal. For example, fruiting bodies of Stigmatella aurantiaca, a well-characterized myxobacterium, are markedly stimulated by red and/or blue light, a physiological response observed nearly 40 years ago but not yet understood. Determining the mechanisms underlying this multicellular process in Myxococclaes can have transformative implications for the evolution of more complex pathways seen in eukaryotes.

We proposed to develop a genetic system for examining and testing the plasticity of the developmental program and take advantage of the recent examples of gene addition and/or subtraction in Myxobacteria with the focus on fruiting body formation. The proposed genetic system would be used to support exploratory work on how light controls fruiting body formation in Myxobacteria, focusing on genes that code for a) the bacterial photoreceptors that perceive and respond to light and b) the circadian clock KaiC homolog of cyanobacteria found across all three suborders of Myxococcales. Genetically, the best characterized M. xanthus doesn’t contain either of these genes, but closely related M. fulvus does. By using a comparative analysis of closely related, yet distinctly different species, M. xanthus and M. fulvus, we were able to approach this question without the complexity inherent with more diverse Myxobacteria. While we are still developing the genetic tools to define photomorphogenic development in M. fulvus using functional analysis of a single red-light photoreceptor and a circadian clock gene, we made significant progress in characterizing the biochemical functions of the respective proteins.

We successfully determined the crystal structures of two BphPs from S. aurantiaca and revealed unique photocycle features for each. We investigated the mechanism of fruiting body formation in myxobacteria with respect to light. We published S. aurantiaca fruiting body formation under blue, red and far-red light and presented data on M. fulvus and M. xanthus fruiting body formation under different light conditions. Interestingly, we were able to demonstrate that S. aurantiaca fruiting bodies do not form under red, but readily appear under far-red light (specific wavelengths of light that BphPs respond to). We also demonstrated evidence of circadian rhythm in M. fulvus and M. xanthus by growing fruiting bodies under different light : dark conditions.

Broader Impact. In the last year, we authored and co-authored two publications in high impact Structural Dynamics and the International Union of Crystallography Journals with more than ten undergraduate and graduate students as co-authors. The PI’s tenure home, Northeastern Illinois University, became a notable center for research with students receiving research awards for their accomplishments at regional and national meetings. We reported results relevant to the EAGER grant at four invited guest lectures for the PI, including workshops and international conferences. Graduate students presented posters at two international conferences, the 46th International Meeting on the Biology of the Myxobacteria, Houston, TX and the 6th BioXFEL conference, San Diego, CA. Undergraduate students presented two posters at the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), Indianapolis, Indiana, and the regional Luis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) conference, Lisle, IL. The PI teaches a course in Molecular Biology, which covers relevant techniques required to perform successful genetic manipulations and utilize the most modern tools for gene characterization in vivo. The students in the course will learn some of the methods that we utilized in the EAGER proposal to develop genetic tools for characterization of the novel genes in Myxococcales. Furthermore, we collaborated nationally and internationally with leaders in the field and provided ample opportunity for our undergraduate and graduate students to lead experiments at the world’s synchrotron and XFEL sources as well as to network within our collaborations. We are now able combine modern genetic tools with biochemical methods at pulsed X-ray sources to investigate important enzymes for a better understanding of structural dynamics, catalysis and the molecular basis of life, specifically photomorphogenesis of myxobacteria.
